This is a good place for adding tips, tricks, bugs and experiences which would help other owners of players in the Sandisk Sansa e200 series, which consists of: *Sansa e250 - 2 gig *Sansa e260 - 4 gig *Sansa e270 - 6 gig *Sansa e280 - 8 gig
SanDisk was the first manufacturer to release an 8 gig flash mp3 player. Sandisk released the e280 model on August 21, 2006.
In addition, you can add [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MicroSD microSD cards], and the battery is user exchangeable.
== Tips and Tricks ==
=== '''Blue Wheel on, Screen off''' ===
If your blue wheel is on, and the screen does not "power on" then hold down the menu button on the front bottom left of the player for about 30 seconds. After 15 the blue wheel will power off, but keep the button pressed down. This allows for a reboot.
=== '''Recovery Mode''' ===
I was having a problem with my player and after a little back and forth they showed me a back door to recover the system:
If your Player wants you to start in recovery mode
'''1.''' Activate the "HOLD" function '''2.''' Press "Rec" and hold, while ath the same time pressing "ON/OFF" button and hold.
After some seconds of pressing there appears a screen reading: Recovery mode: Connect cable Now connect to your PC. A folder 16mbFORMAT will appear under 'My Computer'. Call SanDisk technical support for the most up to date firmware files. 1-866-SanDisk
Note: The firmware is available online via links in their forum at http://forums.sandisk.com/sansa/
There are currently 2 version of the e200s, make sure you get the proper firmware for your version.
Copy the .MI4 file from the zip to the 16mbFORMAT folder.
The one thing not mentioned is to format the device completely, create a new directory called "sansa.fmt" in the 16mbFORMAT folder. Then, unplug the USB cable from your computer. Powering down will not reformat.
=== Playback in Correct Order ===
There are bugs where albums don't always play in the correct order. The first thing you should is download the latest firmware version from Sansa using their firmware updater program available on the site. The latest version should solve this quite easily.
If all else fails, then edit ID3 tags so that the track numbers contain a leading zero. [http://www.mp3tag.de/en/ MP3Tag] (freeware) and [http://maniactools.com/soft/mp3tag-pro/index.shtml mp3Tag Pro] (shareware) work well for this.
=== Change Video Quality ===
If you want to change the quality of the converted videos (results in smaller size), go to the folder Programs Files → Sandisk → Sansa Media Converter → Profiles, then open the the arp file (SanDisk_E200_MSC.apr) in WordPad or Notepad, go to the optimize section and you can change the quality via video quality. I changed mine from 70 to 30 and it keeps the file about the same size, also you can change the converter from capping it off at 10 minutes, go to split time and change it from 600 (goes by seconds so 600 is 10 minutes) to something like 20,000 and that should do it.
=== Alternative charging methods === Sandisk only provides a USB cable for charging the battery. But if you've got a powered USB hub, it's reported to charge the player. Devices that also send power to its USB but not data (for example, the Xbox 360 and the Playstations 2 and 3, when not employing eyeToy extensions) will charge but not use the 'Connected' dialog. Also any wall adapter to USB (i.e. iPod charger) or any after market adaptations work well too. The Made for Sansa product line sells a SanDisk certified model of this *Note: You can't listen to/play media while the Sansa is plugged into the USB hub on computers. You can, however, on some other chargers. There are several after market products, such as wall and car chargers, that will.
=== Play folders and create playlists === Per default, the e200 series does not provide a feature to simply play a single folder of the player's directory structure. This can be useful if the soundfiles do not have correct ID3 tags or a large number of Files is stored on the player. However, there is a free playlist creator which creates playlists for each folder on the sansa player with one click. it is written in .NET and does not alter the music files (http://www.infosys.tuwien.ac.at/staff/cp/playlist_creator.zip).
=== Driver for Windows 98 === Sandisk does not support Windows 98 for the e200 series of players, so they will not make a driver available. The e100 series driver does not work.
There is an independent driver for m200 series in MSC mode http://www.98-drivers.com/sandisk.html There is also a free generic USB mass storage driver here: http://www.technical-assistance.co.uk/kb/usbmsd98.php
=== Fill Device Automatically in Windows Media Player + Create instant playlists for transfer === Peter Gabriel's latest digital venture 'The Filter' have recently released a Windows Media Player and Sansa. This software makes updating your Sansa a very simple process - all you need to do is select a song that you like and a playlist will be instantly generated. This playlist will automatically updated with new songs when you reconnect your device. It is a free download. (http://www.thefilter.com/download.aspx?platform=Windows).
=== Linux Tips === The Sansa E series players (and the Sansa Express) work well under Linux. There are some "gotchas", however:
*'''Mode''' The Sansa's operate in "MSC" mode under Linux. This is not the default mode for the player. You must change the USB mode, the last menu item under the "Settings->USB" menu, to MSC. *'''Sync''' After writing files to the Sansa, you should issue a manual "sync" command, then unmount the device. *'''Important''' The database which stores all of the track info does not automatically update when the USB storage device is ejected. After adding music to your Sansa you '''must''' delete the database directory. When you restart your player the database will be recreated properly. *'''Playlist creation''' You can upload custom playlist into PLAYLISTS folder in the device. Playlist is in PLP format with .pla suffix, UTF-16LE encoded. [http://home.tiscali.cz/sikorsky/sansa Here] is very simple Linux shell script, converting M3U to PLA. Also, see (referenced by parent links below) [http://www.anythingbutipod.com/forum/forumdisplay.php?f=81 Linux Playlist utils]. *More to come...
==Themes== The firmware inside the e200 series can be modified with [http://www.cerebus.de/iriver/ H3 Mod] to customize menu and user interface of the Sansa. Also called "Themeing", these Photoshop artistes create vivid and interesting themes, see Other Links.
== Bugs == '''Song tags in MSC mode'''
If you update the tags on your songs and then transfer the files to the player, the database still shows the old tags. Removing the songs, refreshing the database and then reuploading the songs works. You can also remove the database file System\Data\Pp5000.dat. But some songs still have screwy tags on the E270, even after MediaMonkey shows correct tags on the computer. And some songs won't show the correct genre, no matter what you do. The genre will show as unknown. To fix that, remove the ID3v1 tags and use ID3v2.3 tags (not 2.4). Linux users may find that the Sansa can't read tags written by their computer, even ID3v2.3 tags. The tagging program eyed3 has been known to write Sansa-friendly tags in Linux when converting v1 tags to v2.3.
'''Deleting database deletes list of Top Rated Songs'''
This isn't really a bug, just something to keep in mind. When you rate a song, the song file isn't changed, only the database on the player pertaining to that song. So when you delete the database (needed sometimes), you also lose all rating of songs.
'''System noise between tracks'''
Some owners report a system noise between tracks. The noise is the same audio level, independently of the volume setting, so usually only heard during gaps in the playback or at low volume levels. The system noise is supposedly less noticeable with newer firmwares. Some owners say it's still the same even after upgrade. Some say certain earbuds are more susceptible (low impedance, high sensitivity) to the noise than others.
'''MCDI header hides genre'''
Problem: when an MCDI header (Music CD identifier) is included in the ID3v2 tag, the software fails to read the track's genre information. Solution: remove the MCDI header (for example using ID3-TagIT). Note: make sure you refresh the tag database.
==Reviews==
*[http://reviews.cnet.com/SanDisk_Sansa_e270_6GB/4505-6490_7-31684140.html?tag=pdtl-list cnet Sansa e270 review] *[http://www.i4u.com/article5339.html I4U News review] *[http://www.anythingbutipod.com/archives/2006/03/sandisk-sansa-e200-series-review.php Anything But Ipod e200 series review] *[http://www.dapreview.net/e107_plugins/content/content.php?content.264 dapreview.net SanDisk Sansa e260 Review] *[http://thesansa.com/index.php/sandisk-sansa-compehensive-review The Sansa.com review of the Sansa e200]
{{BookCat}}

Hello and '''[[Wikibooks:Welcome, newcomers|welcome]]''' to [[Wikibooks]]!
Here are some tips to help you get started: * You can sign your name on Talk and vote pages using four tildes, like this: ~~~~. * Remember to conduct any editing experiments in the [[Wikibooks:Sandbox|sandbox]]. * Check out our [[Wikibooks:Help|help]] page if you need additional help. * Eventually, you might want to read the [[Wikibooks:Manual of Style|Manual of Style]] and [[Wikibooks:Policies and guidelines|Policies and Guidelines]]. ** Take a look at [[Wikibooks:Naming policy]] * See [[Wikibooks:Template messages|list of templates]] which can save your time * Remember to maintain a [[Wikibooks:Neutral point of view|Neutral point of view]]. * Explore, [[Wikibooks:Be bold in updating pages|be bold in editing pages]], and have fun!
You will find more resources in [[Wikibooks:Community Portal|Community Portal]]. If you want to ask a question, visit the [[Wikibooks:Study help desk|Study help desk]], the [[Wikibooks:Staff lounge|Staff lounge]], [[Wikibooks:IRC channels|IRC channel]] or ask me personally on my talk page.
Good luck! [[User:Boneheadmx|Boneheadmx]] 01:47, 10 April 2006 (UTC)

This is the beginning lesson on family related vocabulary. The prerequisite lessons are the [[Hebrew/Aleph-Bet|Hebrew Aleph-Bet]] and [[Hebrew/Greetings|Greetings]]. Another lesson with more advanced family vocabulary is at [[Hebrew/Family2]].
==Vocabulary== ===Nouns===
; <font size=4>אֵם</font>: mother (f) (singular) ; <font size=4>אִמָהו֗ת</font>: mothers (f) (plural) ; <font size=4>אִמָּא</font>: mommy (f) (singular)
; <font size=4>אָב</font>: father (m) (singular) ; <font size=4>אָבו֗ת</font>: fathers (m) (plural) (Note: The ending, ו֗ת, is usually feminine-plural, but this is an exception. ; <font size=4>אַבָּא</font>: daddy (m) (singular)
; <font size=4>בַּת</font>: daughter (f) (singular) ; <font size=4>בָּנו֗ת</font>: daughters (f) (plural)
; <font size=4>בֵּן</font>: son (m) (singular) ; <font size=4>בָּנִים</font>: sons (m) (plural)
{{Hebrew-Large| אַהֲבָה}} -- love (feminine) ''ahava''
husband, wife
===Verbs===
; <font size=4>אהב</font>: love (root)
===Adjectives=== ; <font size=4>או֗הֵב</font>: loving
==Sentences==
; <font size=4> הוּא אָב </font>: He is a father. ; <font size=4>שָׁלוֹם אֵם</font>: Hello, Mother.
==Exercises== Translate into Hebrew:
He is my father. She is my mother. (Add "ee" at the end to say "my." Example: Hoo avee. (He is my father.)
==Related Lessons== * [[Hebrew/Family2]] * [[Hebrew/People]]

page.title: XML - Managing Data Exchange/Quick Windows installation

revision.text:
Currently (04/05/06) MySQL 5.1 does not come with the installer (Beta Version). Here are instructions to help you with the installation. Details information can be found in the online [http://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/5.1/en/windows-install-archive.html manual ]. If you follow these recommendations correctly, you should need to get rid of any previous MySQL running in your System.
1. Extract the archive to the desired [http://dev.mysql.com/downloads/ install ] directory. Traditionally, the MySQL server is installed in C:\mysql. If you do not install MySQL at C:\mysql, you must specify the path to the install directory in an option file.
2. An option file can be created and modified with any text editor (Wordpad..). For example, if MySQL is installed in C:\someDirectory\mysql and the data directory is in C:\mydata\data, you can create an option file containing a [mysqld] section to specify values for the basedir and datadir parameters:
[mysqld] # set basedir to your installation path basedir=C:/someDirectory/mysql # set datadir to the location of your data directory datadir=C:/someDirectory/mysql/data
I used the option file found in a pevious version of MySQL and just modified it for this version's directory.
3. To start the server, enter this command:
C:\> "C:\someDirectory\MySQL\bin\mysqld" --console
When the server finishes its startup sequence, you should see something like this, which indicates that the server is ready to service client connections:
mysqld: ready for connections Version: '5.1.7-beta' socket: '' port: 3306
The server continues to write to the console any further diagnostic output it produces. You can open a new console window in which to run client programs.
The MySQL server can be started manually from the command line. This can be done on any version of Windows.
To start using MySQL 5.1, you should start a console window and enter this command:
C:\> MySQL -u root
You can stop the MySQL server by executing this command:
C:\> "C:\someDirectory\MySQL\bin\mysqladmin" -u root shutdown
Note: If the MySQL root user account has a password, you need to invoke mysqladmin with the -p option and supply the password when prompted. If you are running another version on MySQL, dont forget to stop the Service.
To Start MySQL as a Windows Service more information can be found in the MySQL 5.1 [http://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/5.1/en/windows-start-service.html?ff=nopfpls Manual ].
[[Category:{{FULLBOOKNAME}}|{{FULLCHAPTERNAME}}]]

revision.comment: moved [[Analysis of Rings and Manifolds/Sequences of numbers]] to [[User:TakuyaMurata/Sequences of numbers]]
revision.text:
The chapter begins with the discussion of definitions of real and complex numbers. The discussion, which is often lengthy, is shortened by tools from abstract algebra. == Real numbers == Let \mathbf{Q} be the set of rational numbers. A sequence x_n in \mathbf{Q} is said to be Cauchy if |x_n - x_m| \to 0 as n, m \to \infty. Let I be the set of all sequences x_n that converges to 0. I is then an ideal of \mathbf{Q}. It then follows that I is a maximal ideal and \mathbf{Q} / I is a field, which we denote by \mathbf{R}. The formal procedure we just performed is called field completion, and, clearly, a different choice of a [[w:Absolute value (algebra)|valuation]] | \cdot | ''could'' give rise to a different field. It turned out that every valuation for \mathbf{Q} is either equivalent to the usual absolute or some p-adic absolute value, where p is a prime. ([[w:Ostrowski's theorem]]) Define \mathbf{Q}_p = \mathbf{Q} / I where I is the maximal ideal of all sequences x_n that converges to 0 in | \cdot |_p. A p-adic absolute value is defined as follows. Given a prime p, every rational number x can be written as x = p^n a / b where a, b are integers not divisible by p. We then let |x|_p = p^{-n}. Most importantly, |\cdot|_p is non-Archimedean; i.e., :|x + y|_p \le \max \{ |x|_p, |y|_p \} This is stronger than the triangular inequality since \max \{ |x|_p, |y|_p \} \le |x|_p + |y|_p Example: |6|_2 = |18|_2 = {1 \over 2} '''2 Theorem''' ''If |x_n - x|_p \to 0, then |x_n - x_m|_p''.
Proof: :|x_n - x_m|_p \le |x_n - x|_p + |x - x_m|_p \to 0 as n, m \to \infty Let s_n = 1 + p + p^2 + .. + p^{n-1}. Since (1 - p)s_n = 1 - p^n, :|s_n - {1 \over 1 - p}|_p = |{p^n \over 1 - p}| = p^{-n} \to 0 Thus, \lim_{n \to \infty} s_n = {1 \over 1 - p}. Let \mathbf{Z}_p be the closed unit ball of \mathbf{Q}_p. That \mathbf{Z}_p is compact follows from the next theorem, which gives an algebraic characterization of p-adic integers. '''2 Theorem''' '' :\mathbf{Z}_p \simeq \varprojlim \mathbf{Z} / p^n \mathbf{Z} where the project maps f_n: \mathbf{Z} / p^{n+1} \mathbf{Z} \to \mathbf{Z} / p^n \mathbf{Z} are such that f_n \circ \pi_{n+1} = \pi_n with \pi_n being the projection \pi_n: \mathbf{Z} \to \mathbf{Z} / p^n \mathbf{Z}.''
The theorem implies that \mathbf{Z}_p is a closed subspace of: :\prod_{n \ge 0} \mathbf{Z} / p^n \mathbf{Z}, which is a product of compact spaces and thus is compact. == Sequences == We say a sequence of scalar-valued functions ''converges uniformly'' to another function f on X if \sup |f_n - f| \to 0 '''1 Theorem (iterated limit theorem)''' ''Let f_n be a sequence of scalar-valued functions on X. If \lim_{y \to x} f_n(y) exists and if f_n is uniformly convergent, then for each fixed x \in X, we have: :\lim_{n \to \infty} \lim_{y \to x} f_n(y) = \lim_{y \to x} \lim_{n \to \infty} f_n(y) Proof: Let a_n = \lim_{n \to \infty} f_n(x), and f be a uniform limit of f_n; i.e., \sup |f_n - f| \to 0. Let \epsilon > 0 be given. By uniform convergence, there exists N > 0 such that :2\sup |f - f_N| < \epsilon / 2 Then there is a neighborhood U_x of x such that: : |f_N(y) - f_N(x)| < \epsilon / 2 whenever y \in U_x Combine the two estimates: :|f(y) - f(x)| \le |f(y) - f_N(y)| + |f_N(y) - f_N(x)| + |f_N(x) - f(x)| < 2\sup |f - f_N| + \epsilon / 2 = \epsilon Hence, :\lim_{y \to x} f(y) = f(x) = \lim_{n \to \infty} f_n(x) \square '''2 Corollary''' ''A uniform limit of a sequence of continuous functions is again continuous.'' === Real and complex numbers === In this chapter, we work with a number of subtleties like completeness, ordering, Archimedian property; those are usually never seriously concerned when Calculus was first conceived. I believe that the significance of those nuances becomes clear only when one starts writing proofs and learning examples that counter one's intuition. For this, I suggest a reader to simply skip materials that she does not find there is need to be concerned with; in particular, the construction of real numbers does not make much sense at first glance, in terms of argument and the need to do so. In short, one should seek rigor only when she sees the need for one. WIthout loss of continuity, one can proceed and hopefully she can find answers for those subtle questions when she search here. They are put here not for pedagogical consideration but mere for the later chapters logically relies on it. We denote by \mathbb{N} the set of natural numbers. The set \mathbb{N} does not form a group, and the introduction of negative numbers fills this deficiency. We leave to the readers details of the construction of integers from natural numbers, as this is not central and menial; to do this, consider the pair of natural numbers and think about how arithmetical properties should be defined. The set of integers is denoted by \mathbb{Z}. It forms an integral domain; thus, we may define the quotient field \mathbb{Q} of \mathbb{Z}, that is, the set of rational numbers, by :\mathbb{Q} = \left \{ {a \over b} : \mathit{b} \mbox{ are integers and }\mathit{b}\mbox{ is nonzero }\right \}. As usual, we say for two rationals x and y x < y if x - y is positive. We say E \subset \mathbb{Q} is ''bounded above'' if there exists some x in \mathbb{Q} such that for any y \in E y \le x, and is ''bounded below'' if the reversed relation holds. Notice E is bounded above and below if and only if E is bounded in the definition given in the chapter 1. The reason for why we want to work on problems in analysis with \mathbb{R} instead of is a quite simple one: '''2 Theorem''' ''Fundamental axiom of analysis fails in \mathbb{Q}.''
Proof: 1, 1.4, 1.41, 1.414, ... \to 2^{1/2}. \square How can we create the field satisfying this axiom? i.e., the construction of the real field. There are several ways. The quickest is to obtain the real field \mathbb{R} by completing \mathbb{Q}. We define the set of complex numbers \mathbb{C} = \mathbb{R}[i] / where i is just a symbol. That i^2 + 1 is irreducible says the ideal generated by it is maximal, and the field theory tells that C is a field. Every complex number z has a form:
:z = a + bi + . Though the square root of -1 does not exist, i^2 can be thought of as -1 since i^2 + = -1 + 1 + i^2 + = -1. Accordingly, the term is usually omitted. '''2 Exercise''' ''Prove that there exists irrational numbers a, b such that a^b is rational.'' === Sequences === ''2 Theorem''' ''Let s_n be a sequence of numbers, be they real or complex. Then the following are equivalent: * (a) s_n converges. * (b) There exists a cofinite subsequence in every open ball. '''Theorem (Bolzano-Weierstrass)''' ''Every infinite bounded set has a non-isolated point.''
Proof: Suppose S is discrete. Then S is closed; thus, S is compact by Heine-Borel theorem. Since S is discrete, there exists a collection of disjoint open balls S_x containing x for each x \in S. Since the collection is an open cover of S, there exists a finite subcover \{ S_{x_1}, S_{x_2}, ..., S_{x_n} \}. But :S \cap (\{ S_{x_1} \cup S_{x_2} \cup ... S_{x_n} \} = \{ x_1, x_2, ... x_n \} This contradicts that S is infinite. \square. '''2 Corollary''' ''Every bounded sequence has a convergent subsequence.'' Proof: The definition of convergence given in Ch 1 is general enough but is usually inconvenient in writing proofs. We thus give the next theorem, which is more convenient in showing the properties of the sequences, which we normally learn in Calculus courses. In the very first chapter, we discussed sequences of sets and their limits. Now that we have created real numbers in the previous chapter, we are ready to study real and complex-valued sequences. Throughout the chapter, by numbers we always means real or complex numbers. (In fact, we never talk about non-real and non-complex numbers in the book, anyway) Given a sequence a_n of numbers, let E_j = \{ a_j, a_{j+1}, \cdot \}. Then we have: {| |- |\limsup_{j \rightarrow \infty} a_n |= \limsup_{j \rightarrow \infty} E_j |- | |= \bigcap_{j=1}^{\infty}\bigcup_{k=j}^{\infty}E_k |- | |= \bigcap_{j=1}^{\infty} \sup \{ a_k, a_{k+1}, ... \} |} The similar case holds for liminf as well. '''Theorem''' ''Let s_j be a sequence. The following are equivalent: *(a) ''The sequence s_j converges to s.'' *(b) ''The sequence s_j is Cauchy; i.e., |s_n - s_m| \to 0 as n, m \to \infty.'' *(c) ''Every convergent subsequence of s_j converges to s.'' *(d) ''\limsup_{j \to \infty} s_j = \liminf_{j \to \infty} s_j.'' *(e) ''For each \epsilon > 0, we can find some real number N (i.e., N is a function of \epsilon) so that'' *:|s_j - s| < \epsilon for j \ge N. Proof: From the triangular inequality it follows that: :|s_n - s_m| \le |s_n - n| + |s_m - m|. Letting n, m \to \infty gives that (a) implies (b). Suppose (b). The Bolzano-Weierstrass theorem states that every bounded sequence has a convergent subsequence, say, s_k. Thus, :{| |- ||s_n - s| |= |s_n - s_m + s_m - s| |- | |\le |s_n - s_m| + |s_m - s| |- | |< \epsilon \ 2 + \epsilon \ 2 = \epsilon |}. Therefore, s_j \to s. That (c) implies (d) is obvious by definition. '''2 Theorem''' ''Let x_j and y_j converge to x and y, respectively. Then we have:'' :(a) \lim_{j \to \infty} (x_j + y_j) = x + y. :(b) \lim_{j \to \infty} (x_jy_j) = xy. Proof: Let \epsilon > 0 be given. (a) From the triangular inequality it follows: :|(x_j + y_j) - (x + y)| = |x_j - x| + |y_j - y| < {\epsilon \over 2} + {\epsilon \over 2} = \epsilon where the convergence of x_j and y_j tell that we can find some N so that :|x_j - x| < {\epsilon \over 2} and |y_j - y| < {\epsilon \over 2} for all j > N. (b) Again from the triangular inequality, it follows: :{| |- ||x_j y_j - xy| |= |(x_j - x)(y_j - y + y) + x(y_j - y)| |- | |\le |x_j - x|(1 + |y|) + |x| |y_j - y| |- | |\to 0 as j \to \infty |} where we may suppose that |y_j - y| < 1. \square Other similar cases follows from the theorem; for example, we can have by letting y_j = \alpha :\lim_{j \to \infty} (kx_j) = k \lim_{j \to \infty} x_j. '''2.7 Theorem''' ''Given \sum a_n in a normed space:
* ''(a) \sum \left \Vert a_n \right \Vert converges.'' * ''(b) The sequence \left \Vert a_n \right \Vert^{1 \over n} has the upper limit a^*< 1.'' (Archimedean property) * ''(c) \prod (a_n + 1) converges.'' Proof: If (b) is true, then we can find a N > 0 and b such that for all n \ge N: :\left\| a_n \right\|^{1 \over n} < b < 1. Thus (a) is true since:, :\sum_1^{\infty} \left \Vert a_n \right \Vert = a + \sum_N^{\infty} \left \Vert a_n \right \Vert \le a + \sum_0^\infty b^n = a + {1 \over 1 - b} if a = \sum_1^{N-1}. === Continuity === Let f:\Omega \to \mathbb{R} \cup \{\infty, -\infty\}. We write \{ f > a \} to mean the set \{ x : x \in \Omega, f(x) > a \}. In the same vein we also use the notations like \{f < a\}, \{f = a\}, etc. We say, u is ''upper semicontinuous'' if the set \{ f < c \} is open for every c and ''lower semicontinuous'' if -f is upper semicontinuous. '''2 Lemma''' ''The following are equivalent.'' * ''(i) u is upper semicontinuous.'' * ''(ii) If u(z) < c, then there is a \delta > 0 such that \sup_{|s-z|<\delta} f(s) < c.'' * ''(iii) \limsup_{s \to z} u(s) \le u(z)''. Proof: Suppose u(z) < c. Then we find a c_2 such that u(z) < c_2 < c. If (i) is true, then we can find a \delta > 0 so that \sup_{|s-z|<\delta} u(s) \le c_2 < c. Thus, the converse being clear, (i) \iff (ii). Assuming (ii), for each \epsilon > 0, we can find a \delta_\epsilon > 0 such that \sup_{|s-z|<{\delta_\epsilon}}u(s) < u(z) + \epsilon. Taking inf over all \epsilon gives (ii) \Rightarrow (iii), whose converse is clear. \square '''2 Theorem''' ''If u is upper semicontinuous and < \infty on a compact set K, then u is bounded from above and attains its maximum.''
Proof: Suppose u(x) < \sup_K u for all x \in K. For each x \in K, we can find g(x) such that u(x) < g(x) < \sup_K u. Since u is upper semicontinuous, it follows that the sets \{u < g(x)\}, running over all x \in K, form an open cover of K. It admits a finite subcover since K is compact. That is to say, there exist x_1, x_2, ..., x_n \in K such that K \subset \{u < g(x_1)\} \cup \{u < g(x_1)\} \cup ... \{u < g(x_n)\} and so: :\sup_K u \le \max \{ g(x_1), g(x_2), ..., g(x_n) \} < \sup_K u, which is a contradiction. Hence, there must be some z \in K such that u(z) = \sup_K u. \square If f is continuous, then both f^{-1} ( (\alpha, \infty) ) and f^{-1} ( (-\infty, \beta) ) for all \alpha, \beta \in \mathbb{R} are open. Thus, the continuity of a real-valued function is the same as its semicontinuity from above and below. '''2 Lemma''' ''A decreasing sequence of semicontinuous functions has the limit which is upper semicontinuous. Conversely, let f be upper semicontinuous. Then there exists a decreasing sequence f_j of Lipschitz continuous functions that converges to f.''
Proof: The first part is obvious. To show the second part, let f_j(x) = \inf_{y \in E} { f(x) + j^{-1} |y - x| }. Then f_j has the desired properties since the identity |f_j(x) - f_j(y)| = j^{-1} |x - y|. \square We say a function is ''uniform continuous'' on E if for each \epsilon > 0 there exists a \delta > 0 such that for all x, y \in E with |x - y| < \delta we have |f(x) - f(y)|. Example: The function f(x) = x is uniformly continuous on \mathbb{R} since :|f(x) - f(y)| = |x - y| < \delta = \epsilon while the function f(x) = x^2 is not uniformly continuous on \mathbb{R} since :|f(x) - f(y)| = |x^2 - y^2| = |x - y||x + y| and |x + y| can be made arbitrary large. '''2 Theorem''' ''Let f: K \to \mathbb{R} for K \subset \mathbb{R} compact. If f is continuous on K, then f is uniformly continuous on K.''
Proof: The theorem has this interpretation; an uniform continuity is a ''global'' property in contrast to continuity, which is a local property. '''2 Corollary''' ''A function is uniform continuous on a bounded set E if and only if it has a continuos extension to \overline{E}.
Proof: '''2 Theorem''' ''if the sequence \{ f_j \} of continuos functions converges uniformly on a compact set K, then the sequence \{ f_j \} is equicontinuous.''
Let \epsilon > 0 be given. Since f_j \to f uniformly, we can find a N so that: :|f_j(x) - f(x) | < \epsilon / 3 for any j > N and any x \in K. Also, since K is compact, f and each f_j are uniformly continuous on K and so, we find a finite sequence \{ \delta_0, \delta_1, ... \delta_N \} so that: :|f(x) - f(y)| < \epsilon / 3 whenever |x - y| < \delta_0 and x, y \in E, and for i = 1, 2, ... N, :|f_i(x) - f_i(y)| < \epsilon whenever |x - y| < \delta_i and x, y \in E. Let \delta = \min \{ \delta_0, \delta_1, ... \delta_n \}, and let x, y \in K be given. If j \le N, then :|f_j(x) - f_j(y)| < \epsilon whenever |x - y| < \delta. If j > N, then :{| |- ||f_j(x) - f_j(y)| |\le |f_j(x) - f(x)| + |f(x) - f(y)| + |f(y) - f_j(y)| |- | |< \epsilon |} whenever |x - y| < \delta. \square '''2 Theorem''' ''A sequence f_j of complex-valued functions converges uniformly on E if and only if \sup_E | f_n - f_m | \to 0as n, m \to \infty''
Proof: Let \| \cdot \| = \sup_E | \cdot |. The direct part follows holds since the limit exists by assumption. To show the converse, let f(x) = \lim_{j \to \infty} f_j(x) for each x \in E, which exists since the completeness of \mathbb{C}. Moreover, let \epsilon > 0 be given. Since from the hypothesis it follows that the sequence \|f_j\| of real numbers is Cauchy, we can find some N so that: :\|f_n - f_m\| < \epsilon / 2 for all n, m > N. The theorem follows. Indeed, suppose j > N. For each x, since the pointwise convergence, we can find some M so that: :\|f_k(x) - f(x)\| < \epsilon / 2 for all k > M. Thus, if n = \max \{ N, M \} + 1, :|f_j(x) - f(x)| \le |f_j(x) - f_n(x)| + |f_n(x) - f(x)| < \epsilon. \square '''2 Corollary''' ''A numerical sequence a_j converges if and only if |a_n - a_m| \to 0 as n, m \to \infty.''
Proof: Let f_j in the theorem be constant functions. \square. '''2 Theorem (Arzela)''' ''Let K be compact and metric. If a family \mathcal{F} of real-valued functions on K bestowed with \| \cdot \| = \sup_K | \cdot | is pointwise bounded and equicontinuous on a compact set K, then: *(i) \mathcal{F} is uniformly bounded. *(ii) \mathcal{F} is totally bounded. Proof: Let \epsilon > 0 be given. Then by equicontinuity we find a \delta > 0 so that: for any x, y \in K with x \in B(\delta, y) :|f(x) - f(y)| < \epsilon / 3 Since K is compact, it admits a finite subset K_2 such that: :K \subset \bigcup_{x \in K_2} B(\delta, x). Since the finite union of totally and uniformly bounded sets is again totally and uniformly bounded, we may suppose that K_2 is a singleton \{ y \}. Since the pointwise boundedness we have: :|f(x)| \le |f(x) - f(y)| + |f(y)| \le \epsilon / 3 + |f(y)| < \infty for any x \in K and f \in \mathcal{F}, showing that (i) holds. To show (ii) let A = \cup_{f \in \mathcal{F}} \{ f(y) \}. Then since \overline{A} is compact, A is totally bounded; hence, it admits a finite subset A_2 such that: for each f \in \mathcal{F}, we can find some g(y) \in A_2 so that: :|f(y) - g(y)| < \epsilon / 3. Now suppose x \in K and f \in \mathcal{F}. Finding some g(y) in A_2 we have: :|f(x) - g(x)| \le |f(x) - f(y)| + |f(y) - g(y)| + |g(y) - g(x)| < \epsilon / 3. Since there can be finitely many such g, this shows (ii). \square '''2 Corollary (Ascoli's theorem)''' ''If a sequence f_j of real-valued functions is equicontinuous and pointwise bounded on every compact subset of \Omega, then f_j admits a subsequence converging normally on \Omega.''
Proof: Let K \subset \Omega be compact. By Arzela's theorem the sequence f_j is totally bounded with \| \cdot \| = \sup_K | \cdot |. It follows that it has an accumulation point and has a subsequence converging to it on K. The application of Cantor's diagonal process on an exhaustion by compact subsets of \Omega yields the desired subsequence. \square '''2 Corollary''' ''If a sequence f_j of real-valued \mathcal{C}^1 functions on \Omega obeys: for some c \in \Omega, :\sup_j |f_j(c) | < \infty and \sup_{x \in \Omega, j} |f_j'(x)| < \infty, then f_j has a uniformly convergent subsequence.
Proof: We want to show that the sequence satisfies the conditions in Ascoli's theorem. Let M be the second sup in the condition. Since by the mean value theorem we have: :|f_j(x)| \le |f_j(x) - f_j(c)| + |f_j(c)| \le |x - c|M + |f_j(c)|, and the hypothesis, the sup taken all over the sequence f_j is finite. Using the mean value theorem again we also have: for any j and x, y \in \Omega, :|f_j(x) - f_j(y)| \le |x - y| M showing the equicontinuity. \square === First and second countability === '''2 Theorem (first countability)''' ''Let E have a countable base at each point of E. Then we have the following: * ''(i) For A \subset E, x \in \overline{A} if and only if there is a sequence x_j \in A such that x_j \to x. * ''(ii) A function is continuous on E if and only if f(x_j) \to f(x) whenever x_j \to x. Proof: (i) Let \{B_j\} be a base at x such that B_{j + 1} \subset B_j. If x \in \overline{A}, then every B_j intersects A. Let x_j \in B_j \cap E. It now follows: if x \in G, then we find some B_N \subset G. Then x_k \in B_k \subset B_N for k \ge N. Hence, x_j \to x. Conversely, if x \not\in \overline{A}, then E \backslash \overline{E} is an open set containing x and no x_j \subset E. Hence, no sequence in A converges to x. That (ii) is valid follows since f(x_j) is the composition of continuous functions f and x, which is again continuous. In other words, (ii) is essentially the same as (i). \square. '''2. 2 Theorem''' ''\Omega has a countable basis consisting of open sets with compact closure.''
Proof: Suppose the collection of interior of closed balls G_{\alpha} in \Omega for a rational coordinate \alpha. It is countable since \mathbb{Q} is. It is also a basis of \Omega; since if not, there exists an interior point that is isolated, and this is absurd. '''2.5 Theorem''' ''In \mathbb{R}^k there exists a set consisting of uncountably many components.''
Usual properties we expect from calculus courses for numerical sequences to have are met like the uniqueness of limit. '''2 Theorem (uncountability of the reals)''' ''The set of all real numbers is never a sequence.''
Proof: See [http://www.dpmms.cam.ac.uk/~twk/Anal.pdf]. Example: Let f(x) = 0 if x is rational, f(x) = x^2 if x is irrational. Then f is continuous at 0 and nowhere else but f' exists at 0. '''2 Theorem (continuous extension)''' ''Let f, g: \overline{E} \to \mathbb{C} be continuous. If f = g on E, then f = g on \overline{E}.
Proof: Let u = f - g. Then clearly u is continuous on \overline{E}. Since {0} is closed in \mathbb{C}, u^{-1}(0) is also closed. Hence, u = 0 on \overline{E}. \square , and for each j, B_j = \overline{ \{ x_k : k \ge j \} }. Since for any subindex j(1), j(2), ..., j(n), we have: :x_{j(n)} \in B_{j(1)} \cap B_{j(2)} ... B_{j(n)}. That is to say the sequence B_j has the finite intersection property. Since E is coun Since E is first countable, E is also sequentially countable. Hence, (a) \to (b). Suppose E is not bounded, then there exists some \epsilon > 0 such that: for any finite set \{ x_1, x_2, ... x_n \} \subset E, :E \not \subset B(\epsilon, x_1) \cup ... B(\epsilon, x_n). Let recursively x_1 \in E and x_j \in E \backslash \bigcup_1^{j-1} B(\epsilon, x_k). Since d(x_n, x_m) > \epsilon for any n, m, x_j is not Cauchy. Hence, (a) implies that E is totally bounded. Also, [[Image:Hausdorff_space.svg|thumb|right|separated by neighborhoods]] '''3 Theorem''' ''the following are equivalent:'' * (a) \| x \| = 0 implies that x = 0. * (b) Two points can be separated by disjoint open sets. * (c) Every limit is unique. '''3 Theorem''' ''The separation by neighborhoods implies that a compact set K is closed in E.''
Proof [http://planetmath.org/encyclopedia/ProofOfACompactSetInAHausdorffSpaceIsClosed.html]: If K = E, then K is closed. If not, there exists a x \in E \backslash K. For each y \in K, the hypothesis says there exists two disjoint open sets A(y) containing x and B(y) containing y. The collection \{ B(y) : y \in E \} is an open cover of K. Since the compactness, there exists a finite subcover \{ B(y_1), B(y_2), ... B(y_n) \}. Let A(x) = A(y_1) \cap A(y_2) ... A(y_n). If z \in K, then z \in B(y_k) for some k. Hence, z \not\in A(y_k) \subset A. Hence, A(x) \subset E \backslash K. Since the finite intersection of open sets is again open, A(x) is open. Since the union of open sets is open, :E \backslash K = \bigcup_{x \not\in K} A(x) is open. \square === Seminorm === [[Image:Vector_norms.png|frame|right|Illustrations of unit circles in different norms.]] Let G be a linear space. The ''seminorm'' of an element in G is a nonnegative number, denoted by \| \cdot \|, such that: for any x, y \in G, # \|x\| \ge 0. # \| \alpha x \| = |\alpha| \|x\|. # \|x + y\| \le \|x\| + \|y\|. (triangular inequality) Clearly, an absolute value is an example of a norm. Most of the times, the verification of the first two properties while whether or not the triangular inequality holds may not be so obvious. If every element in a linear space has the defined norm which is scalar in the space, then the space is said to be "normed linear space". A liner space is a pure algebraic concept; defining norms, hence, induces topology with which we can work on problems in analysis. (In case you haven't noticed this is a book about analysis not linear algebra per se.) In fact, a normed linear space is one of the simplest and most important topological space. See the addendum for the remark on semi-norms. An example of a normed linear space that we will be using quite often is a ''sequence space'' l^p, the set of sequences x_j such that :For 1 \le p < \infty, \sum_1^{\infty} |x_j|^p < \infty :For p = \infty, x_j is a bounded sequence. In particular, a subspace of l^p is said to have ''dimension'' ''n'' if in every sequence the terms after ''n''th are all zero, and if n < \infty, then the subspace is said to be an ''Euclidean space''. An ''open ball'' centered at a of radius r is the set \{ z : \| z - a \| < r \}. An ''open set'' is then the union of open balls. Continuity and convergence has close and reveling connection. '''3 Theorem''' ''Let L be a seminormed space and f: \Omega \to L. The following are equivalent:'' * (a) f is continuous. * (b) Let x \in \Omega. If f(x) \in G, then there exists a \omega \subset \Omega such that x \in \omega and f(\omega) \subset G. * (c) Let x \in \Omega. For each \epsilon > 0, there exists a \delta > 0 such that :|f(y) - f(x)| < \epsilon whenever y \in \Omega and |y - x|< \delta * (e) Let Proof: Suppose (c). Since continuity, there exists a \delta > 0 such that: :|f(x_j) - f(x)| < \epsilon whenever |x_j - x| < \delta The following special case is often useful; in particular, showing the sequence's failure to converge. '''2 Theorem''' ''Let x_j \in \Omega be a sequence that converges to x \in \Omega. Then a function f is continuous at x if and only if the sequence f(x_j) converges to f(x).''
Proof: The function x of j is continuous on \mathbb{N}. The theorem then follows from Theorem 1.4, which says that the composition of continuous functions is again continuous. \square. '''2 Theorem''' ''Let u_j be continuous and suppose u_j converges uniformly to a function u (i.e., the sequence \|u_j - u\| \to 0 as j \to \infty. Then u is continuous.''
Proof: In short, the theorem holds since :\lim_{y \to x}u(y) = \lim_{y \to x} \lim_{j \to \infty} u_j(y) = \lim_{j \to \infty} \lim_{y \to x} u_j(y) = \lim_{j \to \infty} u_j(x) = u(x). But more rigorously, let \epsilon > 0. Since the convergence is uniform, we find a N so that :\|u_N(x) - u(x)\| \le \|u_N - u\| < \epsilon / 3 for any x. Also, since u_N is continuous, we find a \delta > 0 so that :\|u_N(y) - u_N(x)\| < \epsilon / 3 whenever |y - x| < \delta It then follows that u is continuous since: :\| u(y) - u(x) \| \le \| u(y) - u_N(y) \| + \| u_N(y) - u_N(x) \| + \| u_N(x) - u(x) \| < \epsilon whenever |y - x| < \delta \square '''2 Theorem''' ''The set of all continuous linear operators from A to B is complete if and only if B is complete.''
Proof: Let u_j be a Cauchy sequence of continuous linear operators from A to B. That is, if x \in A and \|x\| = 1, then :\|u_n(x) - u_m(x)\| = \| (u_n - u_m)(x) \| \to 0 as n, m \to \infty Thus, u_j(x) is a Cauchy sequence in B. Since B is complete, let :u(x) = \lim_{j \to \infty} u_j(x) for each x \in A. Then u is linear since the limit operator is and also u is continuous since the sequence of continuous functions converges, if it does, to a continuous function. (FIXME: the converse needs to be shown.) \square == Metric spaces == We say a topological space is ''metric'' or ''metrizable'' if every open set in it is the union of open ''balls''; that is, the set of the form \{ x; d(x, y) < r \} with radius r and center y where d, called ''metric'', is a real-valued function satisfying the axioms: for all x, y, z # d(x, y) = d(y, x) # d(x, y) + d(y, z) \ge d(x, z) # d(x, y) = 0 if and only if x = y. ([[w:Identity of indiscernibles|Identity of indiscernibles]]) It follows immediately that |d(x, y) - d(z, y)| \le d(x, y) for every x, y, z. In particular, d is never negative. While it is clear that every subset of a metric space is again a metric space with the metric restricted to the set, the converse is not necessarily true. For a counterexample, see the next chapter. '''2 Theorem''' ''Let K, d) be a compact metric space. If \Gamma is an open cover of K, then there exists a \delta > 0 such that for any E \subset K with \sup_{x, y \in E} d(x, y) < \delta E \subset some member of \Gamma''
Proof: Let x, y be in K, and suppose x is in some member S of \Gamma and y is in the complement of S. If we define a function \delta by for every x :\delta(x) = \inf \{ d(x, z); z \in A \in \Gamma, x \ne A \}, then :\delta(x) \le d(x, y) The theorem thus follows if we show the inf of \delta over K is positive. \square '''2 Lemma''' ''Let K be a metric space. Then every open cover of K admits a countable subcover if and only if K is separable.''
Proof: To show the direct part, fix n = 1, 2, ... and let \Gamma be the collection of all open balls of radius {1 \over n}. Then \Gamma is an open cover of K and admits a countable subcover \gamma. Let E_n be the centers of the members of \gamma. Then \cup_1^\infty E_n is a countable dense subset. Conversely, let \Gamma be an open cover of K and E be a countable dense subset of K. Since open balls of radii 1, {1 \over 2}, {1 \over 3}, ..., the centers lying in E, form a countable base for K, each member of \Gamma is the union of some subsets of countably many open sets B_1, B_2, .... Since we may suppose that for each n B_n is contained in some G_n \in \Gamma (if not remove it from the sequence) the sequence G_1, ... is a countable subcover of \Gamma of K. \square Remark: For more of this with relation to cardinality see [http://at.yorku.ca/cgi-bin/bbqa?forum=ask_a_topologist_2004;task=show_msg;msg=0570.0001]. '''2 Theorem''' ''Let K be a metric space. Then the following are equivalent:'' * ''(i) K is compact.'' * ''(ii) Every sequence of K admits a convergent subsequence.'' (sequentially compact) * ''(iii) Every countable open cover of K admits a finite subcover.'' (countably compact) Proof (from [http://www.mathreference.com/top-cs,count.html]): Throughout the proof we may suppose that K is infinite. Lemma 1.somthing says that every sequence of a infinite compact set has a limit point. Thus, the first countability shows (i) \Rightarrow (ii). Supposing that (iii) is false, let G_1, G_2, ... be an open cover of K such that for each n = 1, 2, ... we can find a point x_n \in (\cup_1^n G_j)^c = \cap_1^n {G_j}^c. It follows that x_n does not have a convergent subsequence, proving (ii) \Rightarrow (iii). Indeed, suppose it does. Then the sequence x_n has a limit point p. Thus, p \in \cap_1^\infty {G_j}^c, a contradiction. To show (iii) \Rightarrow (i), in view of the preceding lemma, it suffices to show that K is separable. But this follows since if K is not separable, we can find a countable discrete subset of K, violating (iii). \square Remark: The proof for (ii) \Rightarrow (iii) does not use the fact that the space is metric. '''2 Theorem''' ''A subset E of a metric space is precompact (i.e., its completion is compact) if and only if there exists a \delta > 0 such that E is contained in the union of finitely many open balls of radius \delta with the centers lying in E.''
Thus, the notion of relatively compactness and precompactness coincides for complete metric spaces. '''2 Theorem (Heine-Borel)''' ''If E is a subset of \mathbb{R}^n, then the following are equivalent.'' * ''(i) E is closed and bounded.'' * ''(ii) E is compact.'' * ''(iii) Every infinite subset of E contains some of its limit points.'' '''2 Theorem''' ''Every metric space is perfectly and fully normal.''
'''2 Corollary''' ''Every metric space is normal and Hausdorff.'' '''2 Theorem''' ''If x_j \to x in a metric space X implies f(x_n) \to f(x), then f is continuous.''
Proof: Let E \subset X and x \in the closure of E. Then there exists a x_j \in E \to x as j \to \infty as j \to \infty. Thus, by assumption f(x_j) \to f(x), and this means that f(x) is in the closure of f(E). We conclude: f(\overline{E}) \subset \overline{f(E)}. \square '''2 Theorem''' ''Suppose that f: (X_1, d_1) \to (X_2, d_2) is continuous and satisfies :d_2(f(x), f(y)) \ge d_1(x, y) for all x, y If F \subset X_2 and (F, d_2) is a complete metric space, then f(F) is closed.
Proof: Let x_n be a sequence in F such that \lim_{n, m \to \infty} d_2(f(x_n), f(x_m)) = 0. Then by hypothesis \lim_{n, m \to \infty} d_1(x_n, x_m) = 0. Since F is complete in d_2, the limit y = \lim_{n \to \infty} x_n exists. Finally, since f is continuous, \lim_{n\to \infty} d_2(f(x_n), f(y)) = 0, completing the proof. \square == Measure == [[Image:Cantor.png|200px|right|Cantor set]] A ''measure'', which we shall denote by \mu throughout this section, is a function from a delta-ring \mathcal{F} to the set of nonnegative real numbers and \infty such that \mu is countably additive; i.e., \mu (\coprod_1^\infty E_j) = \sum_1^{\infty} \mu (E_j) for E_j distinct. We shall define an integral in terms of a measure. '''4.1 Theorem''' ''A measure \mu has the following properties: given measurable sets A and B such that A \subset B,'' * (1) \mu (B \backslash A) = \mu (B) - \mu (A). * (2) \mu (\varnothing) = 0. * (3) \mu (A) \le \mu (B) where the equality holds for A = B. (monotonicity) Proof: (1) \mu (B) - \mu (A) = \mu (B \backslash A \cup A) - \mu (A) = \mu (B \backslash A) + \mu (A) - \mu (A). (2) \mu (\varnothing) = \mu (A \backslash A) = \mu (A) - \mu (A). (3) \mu (B) - \mu (A) = \mu (B \backslash A) \ge 0 since measures are always nonnegative. Also, \mu (B) - \mu (A) = 0 if A = B since (2). One example would be a ''counting measure''; i.e., \mu E = the number of elements in a finite set E. Indeed, every finite set is measurable since the countable union and countable intersection of finite sets is again finite. To give another example, let x_0 \in \mathcal{F} be fixed, and \mu(E) = 1 if x_0 is in E and 0 otherwise. The measure \mu is indeed countably additive since for the sequence {E_j} arbitrary, \mu(\coprod_0^{\infty} E_j) = 1 = \mu(E_j) for some j if x_0 \in \bigcup E_j and 0 otherwise. We now study the notion of geometric convexity. '''2 Lemma''' :''{x+y \over 2} = a \left( a {x+y \over 2} + (1-a)y \right) + (1-a) \left( ax + (1-a){x+y \over 2} \right) for any x, y''. '''2 Theorem''' ''Let D be a convex subset of a vector space. If 0 < a < 1 and f(ax + (1-a)y) \le af(x) + (1-a)f(y) for x, y \in D, then :f({x+y \over 2}) \le {f(x) + f(y) \over 2} for x, y \in D Proof: From the lemma we have: :2a(1-a)f({x+y \over 2}) \le a(1-a) (f(x) + f(y)) \square Let \mathcal{F} be a collection of subsets of a set G. We say \mathcal{F} is a ''delta-ring'' if \mathcal{F} has the empty set, G and every countable union and countable intersection of members of \mathcal{F}. a member of \mathcal{F} is called a ''measurable set'' and G a ''measure space'', by analogy to a topological space and open sets in it. '''2 Theorem (Hölder's inequality)''' ''For 1 \le p \le \infty, if 1/p + 1/q = 1, then :\int |fg|d\mu \le \left( \int |f|^p d\mu \right)^{1/p} \left( \int |g|^q d\mu \right)^{1/q} Proof: By replacing f and g with |f| and |g|, respectively, we may assume that f and g are non-negative. Let C = \int g^q d\mu. If C = 0, then the inequality is obvious. Suppose not, and let d\nu = {g^q d\mu \over C}. Then, since x^p is increasing and convex for x \ge 0, by Jensen's inequality, :\int fg d\mu = \int fg^{(1-q)} d\nu C \le \left( \int f^p g^{-q} d\nu \right)^{(1/p)} C. Since 1/q = 1 - 1/p, this is the desired inequality. \square '''4 Corollary (Minkowski's inequality)''' ''Let p \ge 1 and \| \cdot \|_p = \left( \int | \cdot |^p \right)^{1/p}. If f \ge 0 and \int \int f(x, y) dx dy < \infty, then :\| \int f(\cdot, y) dy \|_p \le \int \| f(\cdot, y) \|_p dy Proof (from [http://planetmath.org/?op=getobj&from=objects&id=2987]): If p = 1, then the inequality is the same as Fubini's theorem. If p > 1, :{| |- |\int |\int f(x, y)dy|^p dx |= \int |\int f(x, y)dy|^{p-1} \int f(x, z)dz dx |- |align=right|(Fubini) |= \int \int |\int f(x, y)dy|^{p-1} f(x, z)dx dz |- |align=right|(Hölder) |\le \left( \int |\int f(x, y)dy|^{(p-1)q}dx \right)^{1/q} \int \| f(\cdot, z) \|_p dz |} By division we get the desired inequality, noting that (p - 1)q = p and 1 - {1 \over q} = {1 \over p}. \square TODO: We can probably simplify the proof by appealing to Jensen's inequality instead of Hölder's. Remark: by replacing \int dy by a counting measure we get: :\|f+g\|_p \le \|f\|_p + \|g\|_p under the same assumption and notation. '''2 Lemma''' ''For 1 \le p \le \infty and a, b > 0, if 1/p + 1/q = 1, :a^{1 \over p}b^{1 \over q} = \inf_{t > 0} \left( {1 \over p} t^{-{1 \over q}}a + {1 \over q} t^{1 \over p}b \right) Proof: Let f(t) = {1 \over p} t^{-{1 \over q}}a + {1 \over q} t^{1 \over p}b for t > 0. Then the derivative :f'(t) = {1 \over pq} \left( t^{-{1 \over p}} a + t^{1 \over q} b \right) becomes zero only when t = a/b. Thus, the minimum of f is attained there and is equal to a^{1 \over p}b^{1 \over q}. \square When t is taken to 1, the inequality is known as Young's inequality. '''2 Theorem (Hölder's inequality)''' ''For 1 \le p \le \infty, if 1/p + 1/q = 1, then :\int |fg| \le \left( \int |f|^p \right)^{1/p} \left( \int |f|^q \right)^{1/q} Proof: If p = \infty, the inequality is clear. By the application of the preceding lemma we have: for any t > 0 :\int |f|^{1 \over p} |g|^{1 \over q} \le {1 \over p} t^{-{1 \over q}}\int |f| + {1 \over q} t^{1 \over p} \int |g| Taking the infimum we see that the right-hand side becomes: :\left( \int |f| \right)^{1/p} \left( \int |g| \right)^{1/q} \square The ''convex hull'' in \Omega of a compact set ''K'', denoted by \hat K is: :\left \{ z \in \Omega : |f(z)| \le \sup_K|f|\mbox{ for }f\mbox{ analytic in }\Omega \right \}. When f is linear (besides being analytic), we say the \hat K is ''geometrically convex hull''. That K is compact ensures that the definition is meaningful. '''Theorem''' ''The closure of the convex hull of E in G is the intersection if all half-spaces containing E.''
Proof: Let F = the collection of half-spaces containing E. Then \overline{co}(E) \subset \cap F since each-half space in F is closed and convex. Yet, if x \not\in \overline{co}(E), then there exists a half-space H containing E which however does not contain x. Hence, \overline{co}(E) = \cap F. \square Let \Omega \subset \mathbb{R}^n. A function f:\Omega \to \mathbb{R}^n is said to be ''convex'' if :\sup_K |f - h| = \sup_{\mbox{b}K} | f - h |. for some K \subset \Omega compact and any h harmonic on K and continuous on \overline{K}. '''Theorem''' ''The following are equivalent: *(a) f is convex on some K \subset \mathbb{R} compact. *(b) if [a, b] \subset K, then *:f(\lambda a + (1 - \lambda) b) \le \lambda f(a) + (1 - \lambda) f(b) for \lambda \in [0, 1]. *(c) The difference quotient *:{f(x + h) - f(x) \over h} increases as h does. *(d) f is measurable and we have: *:f \left( {a + b \over 2} \right) \le {a + b \over 2} for any [a, b] \subset K. *(e) The set \{ (x, y) : x \in [a, b], f(x) \le y \} is convex for [a, b] \subset K. Proof: Suppose (a). For each x \in [a, b], there exists some \lambda \in [0, 1] such that x = \lambda a + (1 - \lambda) b. Let A(x) = A(\lambda a + (1-\lambda) b) = \lambda f(a) + (1-\lambda) f(b), and then since \mbox{b}[a, b] = \{a, b\} and (f - A)(a) = 0 = (f - A)(b), :{| |- ||f(x)| = |f(x) - A(x) + A(x)| |\le \sup \{|f(a) - A(a)|, |f(b) - A(b)|\} + A(x) |- | |=\lambda f(a) + (1-\lambda) f(b) |} Thus, (a) \Rightarrow (b). Now suppose (b). Since \lambda = {x - a \over b - a}, for \lambda \in (0, 1), (b) says: :{| |- |(b - x)f(x) + (x - a)f(x) |\le (b -x)f(a) + (x - a)f(b) |- |{f(a) - f(x) \over a - x} |\le {f(b) - f(x) \over b - x} |} Since a - x < b - x, we conclude (b) \Rightarrow (c). Suppose (c). The continuity follows since we have: :\lim_{h > 0, h \to 0}f(x + h) = f(x) + \lim_{h > 0, h \to 0}h{f(x + h) - f(x) \over h}. Also, let x = 2^{-1}(a + b) such that a < b, for a, b \in K. Then we have: :{| |- |{f(a) - f(x) \over a - x} |\le {f(b) - f(x) \over b - x} |- |f(x) - f(a) |\le f(b) - f(x) |- |f \left( {a + b \over 2} \right) |\le {f(a) + f(b) \over 2} |} Thus, (c) \Rightarrow (d). Now suppose (d), and let E = \{ (x, y) : x \in [a, b], y \ge f(x) \}. First we want to show :f\left({1 \over 2^n} \sum_1^{2^n} x_j \right) \le {1 \over 2^n} \sum_1^{2^n} f(x_j). If n = 0, then the inequality holds trivially. if the inequality holds for some n - 1, then :{| |- |f \left( {1 \over 2^n} \sum_1^{2^n} x_j \right) |=f \left( {1 \over 2} \left( {1 \over 2^{n - 1}} \sum_1^{2^{n - 1}} x_j + {1 \over 2^{n - 1}} \sum_1^{2^{n - 1}} x_{2^{n - 1} + j} \right) \right) |- | |\le {1 \over 2} f \left( {1 \over 2^{n - 1}} \sum_1^{2^{n - 1}} x_j \right) + {1 \over 2} f \left( {1 \over 2^{n - 1}} \sum_1^{2^{n - 1}} x_{2^{n - 1} + j} \right) |- | |\le {1 \over 2^n} \sum_1^{2^{n - 1}} f(x_j) + {1 \over 2^n} \sum_1^{2^{n - 1}} f(x_{2^{n - 1} + j}) |- | |= {1 \over 2^n} \sum_1^{2^n}f(x_j) |} Let x_1, x_2 \in [a, b] and \lambda \in [0, 1]. There exists a sequence of rationals number such that: :\lim_{j \to \infty} {p_j \over 2q_j} = \lambda. It then follows that: :{| |- |f(\lambda x_1 + (1 - \lambda) x_2) |\le \lim_{j \to \infty} {p_j \over 2q_j} f(x_1) + \left( 1 - {p_j \over 2q_j} \right) f(x_2) |- | |= \lambda f(x_1) + (1 - \lambda) f(x_2) |- | |\le \lambda y_1 + (1 - \lambda) y_2. |} Thus, (d) \Rightarrow (e). Finally, suppose (e); that is, E is convex. Also suppose K is an interval for a moment. Then :f(\lambda a + (1 - \lambda) b) \le \lambda f(a) + (1 - \lambda) f(b). \square '''4. Corollary (inequality between geometric and arithmetic means)''' :''\prod_1^n a_j^{\lambda_j} \le \sum_1^n \lambda_j a_j if a_j \ge 0, \lambda_j \ge 0 and \sum_1^n \lambda_j = 1.'' Proof: If some a_j = 0, then the inequality holds trivially; so, suppose a_j > 0. The function e^x is convex since its second derivative, again e^x, is > 0. It thus follows: :\prod_1^n a_j^{\lambda_j} =e^{\sum_1^n \lambda_j \log(a_j)} \le \sum_1^n \lambda_j e^{\log(a_j)} = \sum_1^n \lambda_j a_j. \square The convex hull of a finite set E is said to be a ''convex polyhedron''. Clearly, the set of the extremely points is the subset of E. '''4 Theorem (general Hölder's inequality)''' ''If a_{jk} > 0 and p_j > 1 for j = 1, ... n_j and k = 1, ... n_k and \sum_1^{n_j} p_j = 1, then:'' :\sum_{k=1}^{n_k} \prod_{j=1}^{n_j} a_{jk} \le \prod_{j=1}^{n_k} \left( \sum_{k=1}^{n_k} a_{jk}^{p_j} \right)^{1/p} (Hörmander 11) Proof: Let A_j = \left( \sum_{k} a_{jk}^{p_j} \right)^{1/p_j}. '''4. Theorem''' ''A convex polyhedron is the intersection of a finite number of closed half-spaces.''
Proof: Use induction. \square '''4. Theorem''' ''The convex hull of a compact set is compact.''
Proof: Let f(\lambda_1, \lambda_2, ... \lambda_n, x_1, x_2, ... x_n) = \sum_1^n \lambda_j x_j. Then f is continuous since it is the finite sum of continuous functions \lambda_j x_j. Since the intersection of compact sets is compact and :\mbox{co}(K) = \bigcap_{n = 1, 2, ...} f(\lambda_1, \lambda_2, ... \lambda_n, x_1, x_2, ... x_n), \mbox{co}(K) is compact. \square Example: Let p(z) = (z - s_1)(z - s_2) ... (z - s_n). Then the derivative of p has zeros in \mbox{co}(\{s_1, s_2, ... s_n\}). == Addendum == # Show the following are equivalent with assuming that K is second countable. #* (1) K is compact. #* (2) Every countable open cover of K admits a finite subcover (countably compact) #* (3) K is sequentially compact. Nets are, so to speak, generalized sequences. # Show the following are equivalent with assuming Axiom of Choice: #* (1) K is compact; i.e, every open cover admits a finite subcover. #* (2) In K every net has a convergent subnet. #* (3) In K every ultrafilter has an accumulation point (Bourbaki compact) #* (4) There is a subbase \tau for K such that every open cover that is a subcollection of \tau admits a finite subcover. (subbase compact) #* (5) Every nest of non-empty closed sets has a non-empty intersection (linearly compact) (Hint: use the contrapositive of this instead) #* (6) Every infinite subset of K has a complete accumulation point (Alexandroff-Urysohn compact) {{Subject|An Introduction to Analysis}}

{{recipe}} __NOTOC__ == Ingredients == *1 2⁄3 cup [[Cookbook:Falafel|falafel mix]] *1 1/4 cup water * 1 head red leaf lettuce * 3 tomatoes * 1 cucumber * 1/2 cup [[Cookbook:Tahini Yogurt Sauce|Tahini Yogurt Sauce]]
== Procedures == === Prepare Falafel === * In a large bowl, add water to falafel mix and stir well. * Let stand 15 minutes to absorb the water. * Form mix into 3/4 inch balls.
==== Baked! ==== Baked is delicious and healthy. * Place balls into mini-cupcake tins or onto a cookie sheet. * Bake in oven at 375 for 12 minutes.
==== Fried! ==== For a more traditional falafel ball, * Heat about 1⁄2-inch vegetable oil to 375°F. * Fry balls until brown and crisp (about 3 minutes). * Drain and set aside.
=== Prepare Veggies === * Clean and chop lettuce. * Quarter the tomatoes. Chop again until large bite size. * Peel and slice cucumber.
Toss vegetables with falafels and douse with tahini yogurt sauce. Falafel may be cold or hot for a delicious salad straight outta the PNW.
== Notes, tips, and variations == Thanks to dry falafel mix and the nature of simple salads, this recipe is pretty fast and easy. Look in the bulk bins at your local hippie grocery store for dry falafel mix.
[[Category:American recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Vegan recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Salad recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Bean recipes]] [[Category:Deep fried recipes]] [[Category:Baked recipes]]

{{recipe}}
== Ingredients ==
* 3 tbls sesame butter tahini * 8 oz (220g) plain [[Cookbook:yogurt|yogurt]] or soy based substitute * 2 tbls [[Cookbook:Olive oil|olive oil]] * 1 large [[Cookbook:Lemon|lemon]] * 3 cloves [[Cookbook:Garlic|garlic]]
== Procedure == # Squeeze juice from lemon into bowl or small food processor. # Chop garlic # Combine all ingredients together and mix well.
Makes 1 1/4 cup (300ml) sauce
[[Category:Tahini recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Yogurt recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Sauce recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Recipes_with_metric_units|{{PAGENAME}}]]
==Introduction==

=== Quantifier or qualifier ===
What here is called a qualifier (''for all'', ''there is'') is normally called a quantifier. See [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantification quantification]. [[User:Otto ter Haar|Otto]] 06:32, 10 April 2006 (UTC)
Just took a look here. I am since a while active at [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/User:Otto_ter_Haar wikipedia].

revision.text:
==Aesop's Fables - verse version by Babrius==
I've got a website full of Aesop's Fables.
Which one do we choose?
I'm thinking ''The Tortoise and the Hare'' or ''The Boy Who Cried Wolf''.
There is a Perry translation alongside so think about this as we pick and choose.
--[[User:EuropracBHIT|EuropracBHIT]] 07:36, 10 April 2006 (UTC).
:Would be good as an example for Ancient Greek. [[User:Andreas|Andreas]] 02:49, 27 October 2006 (UTC)
== Phonetics of the Greek Letters ==
In both the "Words I can learn" and the song/story sections of this it doesn't have the phonetic pronunciations. I, as a person without any backround in Greek (like the people who would be reading this), have little clue how to pronounce the greek words nor how to say the fable. Prehapes a phonetic pronunciations should be given. [[User:N1person|N1person]] 14:01, 23 April 2006 (UTC)
== Unsuitable text ==
The "simple story" is totally out of place and also misleading because it is written in a language that is completely antiquated. It differs from today's Greek more than Shakespearean English differs from today's English. See the Wikipedia article on [[w:Katharevousa]] for details. I replaced this text with a children's song. [[User:Andreas|Andreas]] 01:49, 27 October 2006 (UTC)

[[Talk:Cookbook]] == Some really obvious things that need doing: * write [[Cookbook:Yeast]], [[Cookbook:Broth]] * cleanup all our redirects * standardize a case and tense so we can get on with {{Cleanup-lang}} {{French/Texts/National anthems/Header}} ==History of the Anthem== Originally written in German, the Swiss Psalm has been translated into all the official Swiss languages. The Swiss government has written a [http://www.admin.ch/ch/e/schweiz/psalm/history.html history] of the Swiss anthem, known as the Swiss Psalm. The often mentioned three-stanza English translation, exemplified below, is closer to the German lyrics arrangement than the French lyrics arrangement. However the versions by all languages are generally similar in spirit throughout with sentences rearranged or restructured within or beyond a stanza for example. ;German 1st Stanza {{lang|de| :Trittst im Morgenrot daher, :Seh' ich dich im Strahlenmeer, :Dich, du Hocherhabener, Herrlicher! :Wenn der Alpenfirn sich rötet, :Betet, freie Schweizer, betet! :Eure fromme Seele ahnt :Gott im hehren Vaterland, :Gott, den Herrn, im hehren Vaterland.}} ;Common English translation of German 1st Stanza :When the morning skies grow red :And o'er us their radiance shed, :Thou, O Lord, appearest in their light. :When the Alps glow bright with splendour, :Pray to God, to Him surrender, :For you feel and understand, :That He dwelleth in this land. ==The Swiss Psalm== {| !'''French lyrics'''||'''English Translation''' |- |lang="es" xml:lang="es" | '''1re strophe'''
:Sur nos monts, quand le soleil :Annonce un brillant réveil, :Et prédit d'un plus beau jour le retour, :Les beautés de la patrie :Parlent à l'âme attendrie; :Au ciel montent plus joyeux :Au ciel montent plus joyeux :Les accents d'un coeur pieux, :Les accents émus d'un coeur pieux. |width=50%|{{Solution|title=1st stanza|text= :Upon our mounts, when the sun :announces a brilliant awakening :and predicts the return of a beautiful day :The beauties of the fatherland, :speaks to the tender soul :to heaven it joyfully rises :to heaven it joyfully rises :the sentiments of a pious heart :the touching sentiments of a pious heart }} |- |'''2e strophe'''
:Lorsqu'un doux rayon du soir :Joue encore dans le bois noir, :Le coeur se sent plus heureux près de Dieu. :Loin des vains bruits de la plaine, :L'âme en paix est plus sereine, :Au ciel montent plus joyeux :Les accents d'un coeur pieux, :Les accents émus d'un coeur pieux. |width=50%|{{Solution|title=2nd stanza|text= :When a gentle evening ray :plays once more in the darkened woods :the heart feels happier near God, :Far from the vain noises of the plain :the heart at peace is more serene :To heaven it joyfully rises :to heaven it joyfully rises :the sentiments of a pious heart :the touching sentiments of a pious heart }} |- |'''3e strophe'''
:Lorsque dans la sombre nuit :La foudre éclate avec bruit, :Notre coeur pressent encore le Dieu fort; :Dans l'orage et la détresse :Il est notre forteresse; :Offrons-lui des coeurs pieux :Offrons-lui des coeurs pieux :Dieu nous bénira des cieux, :Dieu nous bénira du haut des cieux. |width=50%|{{Solution|title=3rd stanza|text= :When in the sombre night :the thunder bursts with loudness :our heart approaches once more the great Lord; :In the storm and in the distress :it is our fortress :offer Him our pious hearts :offer Him our pious hearts :God, bless us from the heavens :God, bless us from the highest heavens. }} |- |'''4e strophe'''
:Des grands monts vient le secours; :Suisse, espère en Dieu toujours ! :Garde la foi des aïeux, Vis comme eux ! :Sur l'autel de la patrie :Mets tes biens, ton coeur, ta vie ! :C'est le trésor précieux :C'est le trésor précieux :Que Dieu bénira des cieux, :Que Dieu bénira du haut des cieux. |width=50%|{{Solution|title=4th stanza|text= :From the great mountains comes assistance :Swiss, have hope in God always! :Guard the faith of the forefathers, as they did! :On the altar of the fatherland :Place your wealth, your heart, your life! :It is a precious treasure :It is a precious treasure :That God will bless from the heavens :That God will bless from the highest heavens. }} |} ==Questions== [http://www.admin.ch/ch/f/schweiz/psalm/index.html] {{French/Texts/National anthems/Footer}}

<noinclude>{{French/Texts/National anthems/Header}}</noinclude>
==The Anthem== {| !'''French lyrics'''|| |- | :O Belgique, ô mère chérie, :À toi nos coeurs, à toi nos bras, :À toi notre sang, ô Patrie ! :Nous le jurons tous, tu vivras ! :Tu vivras toujours grande et belle :Et ton invincible unité :Aura pour devise immortelle : :Le Roi, la Loi, la Liberté ! :Aura pour devise immortelle : :Le Roi, la Loi, la Liberté ! :Le Roi, la Loi, la Liberté ! :Le Roi, la Loi, la Liberté ! |width=50%|{{Solution|title=English Translation|text= :Noble Belgium - for ever a dear land - :We give you our hearts and our arms. :By the pure blood spilt for you, our Fatherland, :We swear with one cry - You will live! :You will live, always great and beautiful, :And your invincible unity :Will have as your invincible unity :Will have as your immortal emblem - :For King, Justice and Liberty! :Will have as your immortal emblem - :For King, Justice and Liberty! :For King, Justice and Liberty! :For King, Justice and Liberty! }} |}
<noinclude>{{French/Texts/National anthems/Footer}}</noinclude>

i was using this namespace to prototype for the incipient wikibook "longevity", but have since realized the whole project was more suited to a wikipedia "wikiproject", and am thus moving all the content there.

==Being marked up for being a speedy delete==
First of all, the note to be a speedy delete was added by an anonymous user, which IMHO is a form of vandalism. If they really had an issue here, they should have taken it up on this discussion page and tried to resolve the issue. Also, Wikibooks is about much more than just textbooks, and this does qualify as an instructional resource.
Writing a book can be a very painstaking process, and new users should not be expected to get everything down 100% to make it have the "appearance" of a book. Please, if there is a dispute with this book, bring it up here, especially during the initial development period.
I've taken down the VfD and invoked the [[Wikibooks:Deletion policy]] on this content to give you a little bit of breathing room to create this content. Please take advantage of this time period. --[[User:Robert Horning|Rob Horning]] 13:52, 10 April 2006 (UTC)
===Availability of original content=== Some of the content of the deleted Web page mentioned on the opening page here is available on the WayBack server of the Internet Archive at http://web.archive.org/web/20050102210051/www.gmpf.de/index.php/NVidia:Basic_Installation [[User:216.7.19.20|216.7.19.20]] 12:28, 2 September 2007 (UTC)
==There is already a german NVIDIA-Wiibook available== It's available at either http://wiki.mosnis.dyndns.org/NVIDIA in the Developmentversion for different Operatingsystems or in a Linux-Only Version at http://wiki.linux-club.de/NVIDIA licenced not under the GFDL but a CreativeCommons licence. Perhaps someone will help in translating? --[[Special:Contributions/87.78.254.74|87.78.254.74]] ([[User talk:87.78.254.74|talk]])

Avid gamer, especially the older stuff. * Twin Galaxies Sinclair ZX Spectrum Referee. * System Leader at HARP for Sega Genesis/Megadrive & Bally Astrocade. * (Inactive) Confirmer at MARP (not that this is a big achievement!) *Accessible gaming achievements: **Twin Galaxies: [http://www.twingalaxies.com/index.aspx?c=22&p=32176 A.
